New Records: Max Muncy has now reached base in 12 straight plate appearances, tying Reggie Jackson for the most consecutive postseason plate appearances reaching safely.
Key Match Events: Shohei Ohtani and Mookie Betts each hit home runs.
The Dodgers scored multiple runs in the third, fourth, sixth, and eighth innings.
Yoshinobu Yamamoto allowed two earned runs in 4 1/3 innings while striking out eight.
Danny Young threw a 1-2-3 inning in the ninth frame for the Mets.
The Mets' first clean inning since the fourth inning of Game 3 was in the ninth frame.
Pre-Game Insights: The Mets are in a dire situation with few good starting pitching options after Kodai Senga's rough Game 1.
Manager Carlos Mendoza said David Peterson will start in Game 5 after working out of the bullpen all postseason.
Post-Match Reflections: The Dodgers' offense was relentless and exacting, drawing nine walks and adding multiple runs to their lead in each of the third, fourth, sixth, and eighth innings.
The Mets are in a bad place with their offense unable to capitalize on opportunities, despite the Dodgers' bullpen not allowing a run in a win this postseason.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Shohei Ohtani provided a sign of things to come with a leadoff homer in the first inning, his first hit all postseason with the bases empty.
Max Muncy's 12-game on-base streak ties Reggie Jackson for the longest in postseason history.
The Dodgers go down in order in the ninth inning, their first 1-2-3 inning since the fourth inning of Game 3.
Others: Edgardo Henriquez throws a scoreless eighth inning.
The Dodgers' bullpen has not allowed a run in a win this postseason.
The Mets have several options for who pitches in Game 5, and none of them is ideal.
